predicate.note: Frames file for 'strike' based on sentences in financial subcorpus. Verbnet entry hit-18.1, other framed members include batter, beat, dash, kick. Comparison to Chris' old frames file.

role.descr: instrument, thing hit by or with

example.name: instrumental subject
example.text: Sentiment was helped by the small gain made by New York stocks Wednesday despite anxiety over possible effects of the major earthquake that *trace* struck northern California Tuesday.

example.name: agentive
example.text: John struck the fence with a stick.

example.name: reversed syntax!
example.text: Mr. Auvil sees Fujis, in part, as [*-1] striking a blow against the perversion of U.S. apples by supermarkets.
example.arg: the perversion of U.S. apples by supermarkets

example.name: work stoppage
example.text: ``United pilots have shown on a number of occasions they are willing and able *trace* to strike,'' said an executive at Fuji Bank.

example.name: transitive
example.text: Ironically, many of the pilots involved have left Eastern or are still striking the carrier, which filed for bankruptcy protection March 9.
example.arg: the carrier, which filed for bankruptcy protection March 9

example.name: all args
example.text: John struck all of Mary's disparaging remarks about him from her diary.
example.arg: all of Mary's disparaging remarks about him

example.name: all args
example.text: It struck me as a way to get back to what I really want to do.''
example.arg: a way to get back to what I really want to do

example.name: passive with instrument
example.text: The deal, which will involve an initial $ 20 million investment, was struck *trace* with a handshake, he added.
example.arg: *trace* -> The deal, which will involve an initial $20 million investment,

example.name: be careful with 'with' phrases
example.text: John struck a deal with Mary.

example.name: variation on 'initiate'?
example.text: It is also the kind of libel politicians find useful, since it helps them strike a friendly posture on behalf of an important constituency.
example.arg: on behalf of an important constituency

example.name: agentive
example.text: John struck out every time he was at bat.
example.arg: every time he was at bat

example.name: causal agent
example.text: Mary struck John out with a vicious slider.

example.name: arg1 only in metaphors
example.text: But he struck out with the decimal system of metric weights and measures the French had invented.
example.arg: the decimal system of metric weights and measures the French had invented

example.name: legislative process
example.text: John struck out many of the bill's riders.

role.descr: instrument, thing hit by or with

example.name: passivized
example.text: A natural gas rule was struck down *trace* by a federal appeals court.

example.name: transitive
example.text: And he managed *trace* to fend off further advances and even strike up an unlikely friendship with the interloper.
example.arg: an unlikely friendship with the interloper
